description:
Limnospira fusiformis SAG 85.79 is a species of unicellular, freshwater green algae that belongs to the class Chlorophyceae. It is a member of the genus Limnospira, which is characterized by its fusiform (spindle-shaped) cell morphology.

This particular strain, SAG 85.79, was isolated and deposited in the Sammlung von Algenkulturen der Universität Göttingen (SAG) culture collection. As a freshwater species, Limnospira fusiformis SAG 85.79 is typically found in various aquatic environments, such as lakes, ponds, and slow-moving streams.

The cells of Limnospira fusiformis SAG 85.79 are generally elongated and spindle-shaped, with a length of approximately 10-30 micrometers and a width of 3-7 micrometers. The cells possess a single, cup-shaped chloroplast and a prominent pyrenoid, which is a structure associated with carbon fixation and starch storage.

Limnospira fusiformis SAG 85.79 is known to reproduce asexually through the formation of autospores, which are small, non-motile daughter cells that are released from the parent cell and develop into new individuals.

This species has been studied for its potential applications in biofuel production, wastewater treatment, and as a source of valuable biochemicals, such as lipids and pigments.
